title: Famine, Vengeance, and Giants
shortSummary: 2 Samuel 21 recounts a severe famine during King David’s reign caused by Saul’s breach of a covenant with the Gibeonites. To atone, David hands over Saul’s descendants for execution, followed by the retrieval and proper burial of Saul and Jonathan’s bones. The chapter concludes with accounts of battles against Philistine giants, highlighting God’s deliverance through David and his men.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - Reign of King David in Israel

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel who seeks God’s guidance to end the famine and executes justice for Saul’s sin against the Gibeonites.

keyCharacters.name: Saul
keyCharacters.description: The first king of Israel whose actions against the Gibeonites bring a famine upon the land even after his death.

keyCharacters.name: Gibeonites
keyCharacters.description: A remnant of the Amorites who were spared by Israel’s oath but later suffered Saul’s violent betrayal.

keyCharacters.name: Rizpah
keyCharacters.description: Concubine of Saul who mourns and protects the bodies of her sons after their execution.

keyCharacters.name: Abishai
keyCharacters.description: David’s warrior who rescues him from a Philistine giant attempting to kill him.

definitions.definition: A Canaanite people who deceived Israel into making a covenant with them (Joshua 9), later protected by Israel’s oath.
The act of making amends or reparation for sin or wrongdoing, restoring a right relationship with God.
An ancient unit of weight and currency; here, used to describe the heavy weight of a spear.
A coarse fabric worn as a sign of mourning, repentance, or distress.
A tomb or burial place, often a rock-cut grave.

outline.heading: The Famine and Its Cause
outline.description: A three-year famine prompts David to seek God’s direction, revealing it is due to Saul’s violation against the Gibeonites, descendants of the Amorites with whom Israel had sworn peace.

outline.heading: David’s Justice and the Execution of Saul’s Descendants
outline.description: David hands over seven of Saul’s sons to the Gibeonites for execution to atone for Saul’s sin. Rizpah mourns and protects the bodies until David retrieves Saul and Jonathan’s bones for proper burial, after which God’s favor returns to the land.

outline.heading: Battles Against Philistine Giants
outline.description: David and his men engage in renewed battles with the Philistines, including encounters with giants, demonstrating God’s ongoing deliverance through David’s leadership and his warriors’ valor.

application: Seek God’s guidance in times of crisis, trusting His revelation to address hidden sins or issues affecting your life or community.
Understand the seriousness of covenant faithfulness and the consequences of breaking God-ordained promises.
Demonstrate compassion and perseverance in suffering, as Rizpah’s mourning shows steadfast love and faithfulness even in hardship.
Rely on God’s strength in spiritual battles, remembering that victory comes through faith and God’s power, not human might alone.

keyVerses.text: Then there was a famine in the days of David three years, year after year; and David enquired of the LORD. And the LORD answered, It is for Saul, and for his bloody house, because he slew the Gibeonites.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the direct link between sin and its consequences, emphasizing the need for repentance and divine guidance.

keyVerses.text: And the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son buried they in the country of Benjamin in Zelah, in the sepulchre of Kish his father: and they performed all that the king commanded. And after that God was intreated for the land.
keyVerses.significance: Proper burial and honoring of the dead lead to God’s mercy and restoration, showing the importance of obedience and respect for God’s commands.

keyVerses.text: But Abishai the son of Zeruiah succoured him, and smote the Philistine, and killed him. Then the men of David sware unto him, saying, Thou shalt go no more out with us to battle, that thou quench not the light of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights God’s protection over His chosen leader and the value of preserving the spiritual light of Israel.
